headline: CS(AI) + Math | Stanford University
about: ✯ Hello there! Welcome to my LinkedIn profile! I'm thrilled to connect with like-minded individuals in the dynamic world of technology and innovation. As a passionate and aspiring college student, I am embarking on an exciting journey into the realms of Computer Science, with a focus on the AI track and Product Design. My insatiable curiosity and desire to make an impact drive me to explore the intersection of these fields and the endless possibilities they offer in shaping the future.✯ Throughout my academic pursuit, I am determined to equip myself with cutting-edge technical skills, leveraging my Computer Science education to delve into the fascinating realm of Artificial Intelligence. The potential of AI to transform industries and drive innovation is awe-inspiring, and I'm eager to be part of this transformative journey.✯ Additionally, my interest in Product Design fuels my ambition to understand user behavior and create meaningful experiences through innovative and intuitive products. I believe that combining the principles of design with technological expertise can revolutionize the way we interact with technology and solve real-world problems. I am actively seeking opportunities that align with my interests, where I can immerse myself in the world of product development and startups.✯ I have demonstrated expertise in prioritizing and managing multiple projects within specifications and budget restrictions. I am capable of building consensus among stakeholders to provide breakthrough product strategies and transform complex project initiatives into achievable goals.✯ Furthermore, I have also served as a Science, Writing Center, Berkeley Academy, and Peer Tutor to educate from 9th to 12th standards students about Physics, Chemistry, Biology, or any other science-related subjects.My broad skills include:→ Strategic Planning & Execution→ Product Lifecycle Management→ Continuous Process Improvement→ Requirements & Gathering Analysis→ Troubleshooting & Debugging→ Team Collaboration  Let's connect and explore the possibilities of collaboration, knowledge-sharing, and building a brighter future through technology and design. Whether you're a fellow enthusiast or an industry professional, I'd love to hear from you!Email: rishi.sadanandan25@gmail.com

Saif Ishoof
        
              
          Miami Tech: @A16Z’s Exit - Setback or Setup for Reinvention?

Yes, A16Z is a titan in Venture Capital, but Miami's story isn't defined by one player.

🔭 Let's zoom out & consider the real game-changers for Miami. 

•Commercializing university research.🔬 
•Developing homegrown talent pipeline. 👩‍🎓
•Supporting VCs who are committed to the long journey of Florida & Miami’s innovators.💡
• Leveraging Miami's unique place as a testing ground for ideas, especially at pre-seed. 🌊 
•Ensuring Miami is a place with sufficient opportunity on ramps. 📈

Miami's diversity, global connections, increasing status as a hub of capital remain unmatched. This reset could be our catalyst for a more resilient, diversified tech ecosystem.

Just this week we saw Miami founder, Joey Levy have a successful exit of Simplebet to DraftKings Inc.  

We win as an ecosystem when we play to our own unique strengths, not when we try to duplicate other players like SF or NYC. 

We are running our own race 🚀

Ibrahim Uddin
        
              
          I’m excited to share that I’ve decided to document my journey as I build FinchTech AI into a successful startup. I’ll be sharing what I’ve done so far, my weekly goals, the challenges I face, and the successes I achieve along the way; the good, the bad, and the ugly.

So far, I’ve built my initial website from scratch, established the FinchTech AI brand, and begun developing the MVP for my first AI tool, CalculAI. This tool is designed to assist engineers in selecting the best materials and manufacturing processes. It’s already functional, with a conversational interface that can handle basic material selection tasks, though there’s still work to do.

What I’ve Accomplished:

	•	Trained and integrated a RandomForestClassifier model for material recommendations.
	•	Built a conversational interface for user interaction.
	•	Improved the AI’s ability to handle different scenarios and make better recommendations.

This Week’s Focus:

	•	Enhancing the AI’s decision-making with a decision tree structure.
	•	Improving scenario recognition to make the AI more intuitive.
	•	Implementing a hybrid approach to better guide users through complex decision-making.
    • Start the build of website 2.0.

Long-Term Goals:
My vision is to launch CalculAI as a valuable tool for the engineering industry, secure funding to expand my team, and develop additional AI tools to address other engineering challenges.

Challenges:
With no technical background in software development and experience as a project manager in the engineering industry, I’ve self-taught myself web design and AI development. The journey has been filled with obstacles; many times I’ve wanted to quit, but each day I pushed a little further. Today, I’m proud to say I have a working AI tool, even if it’s just the bare minimum right now (Plan to show a demo later this week) 🚀 .

I’m inviting you all to join me on this journey. If you have advice, I’m all ears, and if you have questions, I’m happy to answer. Let’s connect, share insights, and support each other as we navigate the startup world.

#AI #Startup #Engineering #MachineLearning #TechInnovation #Entrepreneurship #ProductDevelopment #Resilience #Leadership #Innovation

Avirup Sinha
        
              
          🚀 Unlocking the nuances of Product Market Fit (PMF) is key to building successful ventures. It's not just about creating value; it's about capturing it effectively. In the world of startups and innovation, the VC2 framework offers a lens to understand this dynamic interplay.

At its core, PMF is about delivering a product that resonates deeply with customers while addressing a specific market need. But let's dive deeper. PMF extends beyond mere satisfaction, but also validate revenue models, ensuring your offering can be monetized successfully.

Here's where the distinction between creating and capturing value becomes pivotal. To capture value, you must first create it. 
In the realm of macroeconomics, value creation translates to enhancing customer experiences in B2C scenarios or boosting profitability for B2B entities. Pricing models play a crucial role here, as they must strike a balance between delivering value and capturing it.

Ultimately, the success of any product hinges on its ability to generate sustainable revenue. If a product or service fails to do so, its long-term viability comes into question. 

In essence, PMF isn't just about creating buzz; it's about building a solid foundation for sustainable growth. By understanding the intricate dance between value creation and capture, entrepreneurs can steer their ventures towards lasting success. 

Courtesy : Harvard Kennedy School and The Lean Product Playbook.

#ProductMarketFit #BusinessStrategy #Entrepreneurship #VC2

Gabriel Jarrosson
        
              
          What Actually Gets You Into YC?

Have you read Saad Bencherif’s recent piece about his journey to YC acceptance? His insights are fascinating.

Most founders get the application process completely wrong. They think it's about perfect preparation and polished pitches.

But here's what actually worked for his team-

Their failed interview = 3 days of intense prep and mock interviews…
• They got "destroyed" by Michael Seibel because they were too rehearsed, too rigid.

Their successful interview = Zero preparation.
• But backed by a year of actually running their business, understanding their market, and knowing their numbers cold.

The difference was the deep understanding that only comes from doing the work… not a better pitch.

Another counter-intuitive insight from Saad: YC partners send rejection emails that aren't always just rejections. When they suggest pivoting "and letting them know," they mean it. Many successful YC founders took this path.

His data point about application time is telling too. Each reapplication took just 30 minutes - simple progress updates rather than complete rewrites.

This matches perfectly with YC's philosophy -- spend your time building, not perfecting applications.

The real secret to getting into YC is about having a real story to tell.

Chris Kong
        
              
          🚀 Robotics: Redesigning Industries, Transforming Tomorrow 🚀

In my latest Substack post, I explore a topic that’s not just exciting but transformative: robotics. From addressing labor shortages to reimagining entire industries, robotics is moving beyond automation into a realm of exponential possibilities.

Here are a few key takeaways:
1️⃣ The “Why Now” Moment: Robotics today is where self-driving was a decade ago—poised for exponential growth, driven by breakthroughs in AI, machine learning, and Industry 4.0.

2️⃣ Critical Challenges: Data scarcity and hardware costs are significant bottlenecks, as highlighted by Freda Duan (Altimeter Capital). However, with visionary founders and bold, first-principles thinking, these challenges can transform into opportunities for breakthrough innovation.

3️⃣ The Right Approach: Robotics shouldn’t just optimize workflows; it should enable full-stack transformations where robots power safer, faster, and smarter systems at scale.

I had the privilege of learning from and collaborating with some brilliant minds in crafting this piece. Special thanks to Daniel Theobald (MassRobotics) and Wei Ding (Under Control Robotics) for their invaluable insights that shaped many of the themes in this post. I’m also grateful for thought-provoking past conversations with Stefan Seltz-Axmacher (Polymath Robotics), David Li (BHP Ventures), Lawrence Wong (Tesla), and the Optimus team from Tesla’s Robotaxi event, which helped me think critically about where to focus and find the right voices for deeper exploration.

Big shoutout to Jaireh Tecarro and Jen Liao for their incredible feedback and support—your input made this better. 🙏

If robotics fascinates you as much as it does me, check out the post and let me know your thoughts. Would also love it if you could share this with others who might find value in it. Let’s reimagine the future together.

👉 [Link in the comments]

          Summary: The article discusses NASA's mission to Mars to collect rocks, the growing opportunity for startups in the space industry, latest venture capital news, and a breakdown of a16z's $7.2 billion worth of new funds.

Key takeaways:
NASA's mission to Mars to collect rocks was expected to cost $11 billion and take a long time, but with open input from startups, the cost and timeline may improve.
Startups are increasingly interested in the space industry, as shown by Two Chairs' Series C funding and Quilt's recent fundraising for heat pump work.
a16z's recent announcement of $7.2 billion worth of new funds indicates their continued success and shows they are unaffected by the current venture slowdown.

Counter arguments:
Some may argue that the cost and timeline for NASA's mission to Mars is not feasible, even with support from startups.
While a growth in startups in the space industry is promising, there is still a long way to go before it becomes a major player in the startup world.

#venturecapital #vc #venture #startups

Taiki Chung
        
              
          How you can become a Venture Capitalist … without ANY money! 🤯

I sat down with Alex Pattis, the King of SPVs and the General Partner of Riverside Ventures, to break down a unique way to invest in your favorite private companies. A normal VC firm pools capital together to create a fund and invests out of that fund. The syndicate system invests in startups on a deal by deal basis! If any of that is confusing to you, and you want to start VC investing without any of your own money, make sure you listen to Ep 019 of “New to Venture”!

Key Takeaways:

1️⃣ Provide value first. Try your best to be helpful! Don’t just say it, find ways to do it. Many VCs are ridiculed for saying “Let me know how I can be helpful” but never actually being helpful. Try to not be that person. 

2️⃣ VC funds follow a 2 and 20 structure, meaning that 2% of the fund is given to the firm every year to manage the money and after the firm returns the fund they get to keep 20% of the profits. An SPV structure is similar, but there are 2 main differences. For early stage investments, the management fees are negotiable, nonexistent, a one time fee, or lower than 2%. Second, SPVs don’t have to return an entire fund's worth of capital before they see a dollar of profit, just the initial investment amount. 

3️⃣ Signaling plays a huge role in the world of syndicates. Since a syndicate lead has to raise money from LPs on every deal, good signaling (strong co-investors) garner more interest.

4️⃣ When you’re young, you tend to be aggressive about helping with everything. Ultimately, that's a trap, be realistic with what you can actually provide and over deliver on that thing. Under promise and over deliver.

5️⃣ Staying top of mind is difficult. Some best practices include grabbing in-person coffee, quarterly calls, and posting content. Building an online presence is an underutilized method to staying top of mind!

Listen on Spotify: https://lnkd.in/drziG2Mt 

Listen on Apple Podcasts: https://lnkd.in/d4dC6WmC 

#NewtoVenture #VentureCapital #Startups #VC #CEO #Business #Investing #recruiting #networking

Jason Calacanis
        
              
          Silicon Valley Slackers: Myth or Reality?

We sat down with Menlo Ventures’ Deedy Das to discuss his viral tweet about underworked engineers earning $300K+ and the phenomenon’s broader implications.

Mouse Jigglers & Ghost Engineers: Deedy shares wild stories of remote workers gaming the system, from "working" in Mexico for years to productivity software catching patterns of inactivity.

Misaligned Incentives: Deedy argues that middle managers prioritize headcount over productivity, creating an environment where underperformance is overlooked.

Measuring Productivity: Lines of code and git commits aren’t enough. Engineering productivity remains complex and difficult to quantify, so there’s no silver bullet.

Viral Backlash: Deedy’s anecdotes sparked heated debates in tech, with some engineers admitting to coasting while others criticized him for "narking" on the culture.

Should companies rethink how they measure and incentivize performance?

Ege Kaan Duman
        
              
          This is what I learned as a Y Combinator alum

Coming out of YC, I've realized the real founder's life is about so much more than the intensity of a 3-month sprint. It's about the day-to-day grind, making tough decisions, and continuously finding ways to grow—both for your startup and for yourself.

We pivoted, we iterated, and we built. And now, we're in the next phase: talking to users, improving our product, and navigating the rollercoaster of early startup life. Some days are full of wins, and others are full of lessons.

For any founders out there wrapping up YC or thinking about applying: the end of the batch isn't the finish line. It's just the beginning of a long, challenging, and incredibly rewarding journey. Onward!

Lmk if you're navigating a similar path—I'd love to hear your thoughts.

Noah Sheinbaum
        
              
          So, about this "founder mode" thing...

The newest essay from YC founder Paul Graham.

My 2c: the best founders do one single thing:

Get to product-market fit.

Faster is better.

But getting there is what matters.

This can happen with a "scientist" or a "bull."

Scientist: Steve Blank's "lean" methodology... Test hypotheses rigorously. Iterate rapidly. No sacred cows. This can be taught.

Bulls: Jobs. Bezos. Musk. Visionaries. Some people are born with taste. This cannot be taught. Even these luminaries are still often wrong. But their successes are massive and their personalities are world-shaping forces.

FEW are actually bulls. Self-fashioning as a "bull" makes it more likely you will fail if you're not a generational talent (and let's be honest... most of us are not).

Like everything else in the world, just know what game you're playing. 

Since this has been dominating Twitter, and not really permeating LinkedIn, I had to do it...

Go off, let it rip in the comments...

Mikkel K.
        
              
          People overcomplicate startup fundraising
Listen, if you’re a first time founder:

Avoid:
- Long pitch decks to send out < (15 slides IMO) 
- Unreasonable financial projections
- To much focus on your product/features
- Not showing current competition 

Instead:
- Focus on a simple pitch deck that can be skimmed (cause it will)
- Reasonable financial projections with assumptions
- Focus on the investment opportunity vs product
- Show how you are unique vs competition

Do this before you send out your pitch deck again. 

Sent it out from there.

Investment is about multiplying money and getting someone to trust that you are the multiplier. 

Simple yet hard. 

If you want the exact formula for building up a pitch deck that helped me raise over 4 mio usd. 
Connect with me and comment PD and I will sent it to you. 

-MK

All Chance
        
              
          How to Raise a Seed Round by Babson College:

Raising a seed round is a critical step for early-stage startups. Here are key insights to guide you:

1) Define Your Needs: Raise enough for 12-18 months of runway, covering product development, team growth, and customer acquisition. A solid financial model will help outline your cost drivers and revenue potential.

2) Build Your Pipeline: Target investors by considering their stage focus, industry expertise, and network connections. Prioritize introductions and build relationships over a few months.

3) Craft a Compelling Pitch Deck: Keep it to 10 slides covering essentials like your problem, solution, market opportunity, team, and financial projections. Make it clear how funds will be used.

4) Create FOMO: Approach multiple investors simultaneously to create urgency. An anchor investor can help drive momentum and set the terms.

5) Prepare for Dilution: Understand valuation and dilution dynamics. Tools like ownyourventure.com can help model how fundraising impacts ownership.
-----
Follow All Chance to learn from more innovative insights

John Ferry
        
              
          Two hypotheses for the coming Pentagon environment: good for VC-backed and back for VC-backed…

The first hypothesis is pretty straightforward, the sheer number of VC alums and VC adjacent, from the VP to the DepSecDef would logically lend to the idea that the building would naturally get more VC friendly. Not overtly mind you, I don’t see folks rolling in and outright steering funds into companies in which they have interest, more a matter of the folks holding the reins actually knowing how that world works on a deep level and implementing policy that really helps.

The second hypothesis goes like this: the admin has, at best, 18 months to really get changes moving, while they have all three seats of power, before midterm pressures smack an aspirational agenda with the cold fish of reelection prerogatives. Likewise, the best I think we can hope for these private sector titans to take a break from making markets to make $200k/yr as a DC-dwelling bureaucrat, is about two years. That also happens to be the going tenure of an appointee-level official. So the White House and the E Ring have 24 months to make a difference for venture backed firms before the political gravitational pull swings the building back into a regular orbit around the budgetary sun…which is…about 1 1/2 POM cycles…the frozen middle has held there breath for longer before…

I’m probably wrong in bother cases, just a casual observation.
